topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny explains this special compilation episode: 17 favorite interview questions from past guests, meant to help listeners interview better or prepare as candidates.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Sendbird (in-app communications API) and ePO (A/B testing and feature management platform), highlighting key benefits and listener offers.

topics.title: Self-awareness: attributing success beyond luck
topics.summary: Eeke De Miliano shares the question 'To what do you attribute your success?' (without saying luck) to assess self-awareness and reflection on what drove outcomes.

topics.title: Resilience: defining and overcoming hard things
topics.summary: Geoff Charles asks 'What’s the hardest thing you’ve ever done?' to understand a candidate’s bar for difficulty, agency, collaboration, and perseverance.

topics.title: Eigenquestions: teleportation product strategy test
topics.summary: Shishir Mehrotra’s teleportation prompt tests how candidates clarify ambiguity, prioritize the two most important questions, and build a plan from limited information.

topics.title: Handling controversy and compelling product storytelling
topics.summary: Yuhki Yamashita probes how candidates navigated controversial product decisions and whether they can frame problems in a way that rallies others through clear storytelling.

topics.title: Pride in work: values, taste, and motivation
topics.summary: Katie Dill, Karri Saarinen, and Camille Hearst all ask what candidates are most proud of to reveal judgment, values, motivation, and how they define great work.

topics.title: Navigating ambiguity with structure and milestones
topics.summary: Jiaona Zhang emphasizes behavioral questions about ambiguity, looking for candidates who create structure, seek input, and define milestones to validate direction.

topics.title: Unfair secrets: boosting product team velocity
topics.summary: Noah Weiss asks for 'unfair secrets' that improved team velocity/energy, pushing candidates to share learned, practical insights and how they apply them.

topics.title: Future self, curiosity, and values alignment checks
topics.summary: Ben Williams asks what will be different about the candidate in three years to surface humility and growth areas, and notes a strong candidate question about DEIB involvement.

topics.title: Third-person perspective: what siblings say about you
topics.summary: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz uses 'What would your siblings say about you?' to test sincerity and self-awareness, looking for grounded, non-performative answers.

topics.title: Failure mindset: when something went wrong
topics.summary: Paige Costello asks about a time something went wrong to evaluate accountability, learning orientation, and how candidates assess and respond when work fails.

topics.title: Authenticity: challenging conventional wisdom
topics.summary: Nikhyl Singhal asks what widely believed idea is inaccurate to force genuine opinions and break rehearsed interview patterns, revealing authenticity and independent thinking.

topics.title: Introspection: why decisions worked or didn’t
topics.summary: Ayo Omojola probes reflection by asking about outcomes that succeeded for unexpected reasons or good decisions that failed, testing learning and model-updating.

topics.title: Limits and luck: self-knowledge under pressure
topics.summary: Scott Belsky asks what candidates learned about their limitations and whether they consider themselves lucky, assessing introspection, accountability, and comfort with privilege.

topics.title: Defining impact: delivering meaningful outcomes
topics.summary: Lauryn Isford asks about delivering something impactful to understand how candidates define impact and whether they’re intrinsically motivated by business results.

topics.title: Reference calls: performance-review feedback question
topics.summary: Paul Adams shares a reference-check question—what feedback you’ll give in the first performance review—to elicit candid, actionable insights beyond glowing referrals.
